August 23, 1981: Fiction
CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family
seeking peace in rural Maine.
NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese
businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses.
THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Chief of
Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town
businessmen visiting New York.
GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in
Moscow leads to a chase on two continents.
THE GLITTER DOME, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow/Perigord, $12.95.) Two
veteran homicide detectives trapped by the seductive vices of Hollywood.
GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two
randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture.
TRADE WIND, by M.M. Kaye. (St. Martin's, $15.) Love and death in exotic 19th-
century Zanzibar.
THE CARDINAL SINS, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Bernard Geis, $12.95.)
The triumphs and tragedies of two Chicago boys as priests in the Catholic Church.
THE CLOWNS OF GOD, by Morris West. (Morrow, $14.95.) What happens when
the Pope has a revelation that the end of the world is near and the Cardinals force
him to abdicate.
GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam's, $12.95.) Leto continues
as guardian and savior of the human race in the fourth novel about the planet
Dune.
LICENSE RENEWED, by John Gardner. (Richard Marek, $9.95.) James Bond
against a mad nuclear physicist.
FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $10.95.)
Travis McGee investigates the murder of an ailing tycoon.
THE WHITE HOTEL, by D.M. Thomas. (Viking, $12.95.) Sigmund Freud treats a
young woman whose case epitomizes the neuroses of the 20th century.
MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $10.95.) An illustrated fable
about the Sun, the moon and a hidden treasure.
NIGHT PROBE!, by Clive Cussler. (Bantam, $13.95.) A race to recover an
important British-American treaty long lost at sea.
August 23, 1981
Non-Fiction
THE BEVERLY HILLS DIET, by Judy Mazel. (Macmillan, $10.95.) A regimen
devised by a Hollywood nutrition guru.
THE LORD GOD MADE THEM ALL, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) The
further adventures of the Yorkshire vet at home and behind the Iron Curtain.
NEVER-SAY-DIET BOOK, by Richard Simmons. (Warner, $14.95.) A regimen for
exercise, diet and life style devised by a Hollywood television personality.
MISS PIGGY'S GUIDE TO LIFE, by Miss Piggy as told to Henry Beard. (Knopf/
Muppet Press, $12.95.) Advice about everything from the superstar porcine
personality.
THE CINDERELLA COMPLEX, by Colette Dowling. (Summit Books, $12.95.)
From her own experience, a writer argues that women have a hidden fear of
independence.
THEORY Z, by William G. Ouchi. (Addison-Wesley, $12.95.) The reasons for
Japanese business success.
THE HITE REPORT ON MALE SEXUALITY, by Shere Hite. (Knopf, $19.95.) The
performances and practices of 7,239 men, ages 13 to 97.
LIVING ALONE & LIKING IT! by Lynn Shahan. (Stratford Press, $10.95.) How to
enjoy the single life.
HOW TO MAKE LOVE TO A MAN, by Alexandra Penney. (Clarkson N. Potter,
$10.) How-to.
THE EAGLE'S GIFT, by Carlos Castaneda. (Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) Another
journey into the land of sorcery, hallucinatory visions and Mexican Indian lore.
JANE BRODY'S NUTRITION BOOK, by Jane Brody. (Norton, $17.95.) Advice by
The New York Times personal health columnist.
COSMOS, by Carl Sagan. (Random House, $19.95.) Thirteen billion years of the
universe's evolution explained by the NASA medal-winning space scientist.
PRISONER WITHOUT A NAME, CELL WITHOUT A NUMBER, by Jacobo
Timerman. (Knopf, $10.95.) Autobiographical reflections of an Argentine Jewish
newspaperman who was imprisoned and tortured by the army.
KEEP IT SIMPLE, by Marion Burros. (Morrow, $11.95.) Dishes that can be
prepared within half an hour.
YOU CAN NEGOTIATE ANYTHING, by Herb Cohen. (Lyle Stuart, $12.) Ways to
avoid conflict and get what you want.
